The idea also seems very related to Nehaniv's concept of 'empowerment', whe=
re an agent tries to maximize its mobility and future options; there are re=
sults in domains somewhat similar to those in the Physical Letters paper. h=
ttp://scholar.google.com/scholar?hl=3Den&q=3Dnehaniv+empowerment&btnG=3D&as=
_sdt=3D1%2C44&as_sdtp=3D

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Ken" <kstanley@...>=
 wrote:
>
> 
> 
> Hi Greg, thanks to both you and Colin (in his prior post)=
 for pointing out his work.  As a non-objective type of behavioral search, =
it is indeed reminiscent of novelty search.  Like both of you I'm not reall=
y sure if the idea is that new, though it's not entirely the same as anythi=
ng else either.  Another question is whether it has any advantage over easi=
er-to-understand ideas like searching for novelty. A couple concepts that r=
emind me a bit of this work outside novelty search include "homeokinesis" (=
http://robot.informatik.uni-leipzig.de/videos/) and "Maximum Entropy Invers=
e Reinforcement Learning" (which at least sounds quite similar) (http://www=
.aaai.org/Papers/AAAI/2008/AAAI08-227.pdf)
> 
> Best,
> 
> ken
> 
> --- In =
neat@yahoogroups.com, "Greg" <greg_barton@> wrote:
> >
> > http://www.insid=
escience.org/content/physicist-proposes-new-way-think-about-intelligence/98=
7
> > 
> > From the article: 'Entropica's intelligent behavior emerges from=
 the "physical process of trying to capture as many future histories as pos=
sible," said Wissner-Gross.'  
> > 
> > Fairly close to searching for novel=
ty.
> >
